Dear Christy Shillings:
Attached is the Amended Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility.
Due to the violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4431 Heating equipment.
Section
Description (1) Heating equipment shall be capable of maintaining a
temperature of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit at a point 4
feet above the floor. An accurate thermometer shall be provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The building has cluttered vents, no heat, and cold temperatures.
Investigation DCWL received these allegations on 1/22/24 via DCWL online
complaint. The Complainant was listed as Anonymous.
I arrived onsite on 1/25/24 unannounced accompanied by
Government Worker 1. I reviewed the allegations with Chief
Administrator (CA) and Vice President of Residential Services.
Licensee Designee was also present in the building.
Onsite Inspection:
I observed heat vents in the staff bathroom and hallways and saw
no clutter or obstructions. Government Worker 1 and I toured the
facility from basement to the third floor living spaces with Director
of Operations and Facilities. Each floor was warm with portable
thermostats showing temperatures between 72 - 76 degrees.
Documents reviewed:
I reviewed the facility’s history of licensing violations.
The Renewal Report by Former Agency Consultant indicates the
most recent Environmental/Health Inspection completed on
07/28/2023 received an A rating.
Printed internal emails and invoices from Allied Building Service
Company of Detroit showed the facility contracts with this
company to regulate the heat and make various other facility
repairs. Photos taken on 11/30/23 of thermometers showed the
following temperatures: Basement 79.5; First Floor 79.2; Second
Floor 72.3; Third Floor 68.5. Invoice dated 12/1/23 indicated
repairs to furnaces and baseboard heaters were made totaling
$938. Invoice dated 1/18/24 showed a follow up service call
occurred noting boilers/pumps and registers were heating
properly.
3

Interview:
Agency Consultant stated she was at the facility on 1/18/24,
toured the building and felt heat on the first, second and third
floors.
Youth E said the heat was blasting and he asked staff to put on
the air conditioning, but they refused.
Analysis DCWL Consultants felt heat on each floor on 1/18/24 and 1/25/24.
Documents indicate the building has had some issues with heat
regulation and contracts with a company that makes ongoing
repairs as needed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
Section (1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
Description comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be located on
land that is properly drained.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility does not sanitize for the safety of others.
There are no cleaning products provided. Dirty mops reused to
clean.
Investigation Onsite inspection:
When I arrived onsite on 1/25/24, it was noted the conference
room table was freshly sanitized. As I toured the building, I
observed cleaning products, mops and mop buckets in the first-
floor staff bathroom and mop closets on each floor. The
basement storage room had cases of various cleaning products,
dry and wet mop heads, and floor scrubbers.
When I arrived onsite again on 2/7/24, a staff person sanitized the
conference room table in my presence.
Interview
Director of Operations and Facilities informed me that floor staff
and/or youths clean and mop the living areas. When a mop head
is dirty, it should be sent to the laundry in the basement to be
washed and replaced with a fresh mop head from supply room.
Analysis Staff and/or youths are responsible for cleaning and sanitizing the
living areas. The facility was observed with ample cleaning
4

products. When mops are dirty, they should be sent to the
laundry and replaced with a fresh mop head from the supply room.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation ALLEGATION 1
On 1/15/24, an unidentified staff choked an unidentified youth.
Another unidentified staff begged him to release the youth. The
youth was discharged the next day, and the staff went on medical
leave.
ALLEGATION 2
On 1/1/24, an unidentified staff threw an unidentified youth to the
ground and choked him.
Investigation ALLEGATION 1
Documents reviewed:
It should be noted that the only written report for this incident was
authored by Supervisor 1 who was not present when it started.
The incident report dated 1/15/24 at 9:30pm indicated Supervisor
1 was notified of a physical altercation between Staff 1, Youth B
and Youth E. Supervisor 1 arrived at the second floor (lounge)
and observed Staff 1 and Youth B on the floor with a very tight
hold on each other. Supervisor 1, Staff 2, Staff 3 and Staff 4 used
pulling motions and techniques to separate them. While doing so,
Youth E punched and kicked Staff 1 on the ground. Staff tried
their best to remove Youth E. Once Staff 1 was released, other
staff held Youth B and Youth E until Staff 1 was out of the
building. Program Director was notified…Law enforcement
contacted. Ambulance came.
A Behavior Notification by Supervisor 1 at 9:50pm explained why
the ambulance came. It indicated Youth B laid on the bathroom
floor holding his chest signaling he couldn’t breathe. Asked if he
5

was okay, Youth B said “Bitch, fuck you” and held his chest again.
After seeing his chest rise and fall very fast, ambulance was
contacted. This occurred (20 minutes) after Youth B had physical
altercation with Staff 1.
Hospital discharge instructions from Beaumont Emergency
Department dated 1/16/24 indicated Youth B was diagnosed with
Neck Sprain, also known as a pulled muscle. No treatment was
provided.
Interviews:
I interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) jointly with Government
Worker 1 on 1/25/24. She said Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3 or Staff 4
did not write incident reports, but she would obtain written
statements. By 2/7/24, no written statements or additional
incident reports were provided.
CA stated Youth B was being supervised on 1:1 by Staff 1 when
this event took place. She refuted the allegation and clarified that
Staff 1 did not attack Youth B, but rather Youths B and E attacked
him. She said Detroit Police were shown video of the incident
and identified Youth B as the aggressor. The police contacted the
Wayne County Juvenile Detention Center requesting approval to
transport Youth B and Youth E there. Permission was denied,
and both youths remained at Wolverine Center. Staff 1 was
injured and still on medical leave as a result of the incident.
Supervisor 1 was “written up” for writing a misleading incident
report. Youth B was discharged the day after the incident
(1/16/24) to Muskegon MDHHS. Youth E was discharged to
another facility the last week in January 2024.
Courtesy Worker interviewed Youth B at Muskegon County
Juvenile Transition Center on 2/8/24. No visible marks or bruises
were observed. Youth B recalled being at Wolverine Center and
told her things were fine there. With additional prompting, Youth B
stated there was a fight where a staff took him by the neck and
choked him. While the staff choked him, Youth B said he threw up
and the staff let him go. Youth B refused to name the staff stating
he wanted his name left out of reports and court documents. After
being choked, he said he received medical attention. He denied
any other incidents occurred at Wolverine Center.
On 2/7/24 I interviewed Youth E jointly with Government Worker 1
via Teams. Youth E presented with a silly non-serious demeanor,
laughing and untruthful about the facts relative to the incidents he
was involved in at Wolverine Center.
6

Youth E was vague regarding this specific incident. He stated
Youth B wanted to call a supervisor. “A fight was gonna start and
ain’t nobody want no charges so I covered the camera. Youth B
pushed Staff 1 three times. Staff 1 put Youth B in a choke hold.
Staff 1 got hit a couple times by another youth.” Youth E claimed
he did not know who hit Staff 1, but video showed it was actually
him (Youth E) hitting Staff 1.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 on 2/7/24.
He has worked at the facility for four years and returned from
medical leave on 1/26/24. Regarding the incident, Staff 1 said it
was bedtime and he was in the lounge with Youth B when
Manager asked the youth to turn the game off. Youth B asked
Staff 1 to text a different supervisor and get permission to continue
the game. Then Youth B asked to see Staff 1’s phone to check if
he texted the supervisor. When Staff 1 refused to show Youth B
his phone, Youth B called out for Youth E. Youth E arrived at the
lounge and the boys sat close whispering. Youth B asked why
Staff 1 was still in the room and told Youth E to cover up the
camera. Youth E covered the camera. Staff 1 said he responded
by standing in a protective stance and attempted verbally de-
escalating the youth. “Youth B ignored me and kicked a big chair
toward me. He punched me in the chest. I grabbed him and we
fell on the floor together. Youth B was trying to get on top of me.
Youth E tried to drag me. I got in a rear-naked position.”
Asked to explain a “rear-naked position” Staff 1 said it is a
wrestling move. He explained he was alone with Youths B and
Youth E and they overpowered him. Staff 1 felt “unsafe” and
resorted to “fight or flight” mode. “I had no help until four- or five-
minutes in. (On the floor) I had my legs wrapped around Youth B
and blocked his arms from grabbing me as well. I was just waiting
for help repeatedly getting hit in my head by Youth E. I ended up
with bruised ribs and a cervical spine contusion.” Once several
staff arrived at the room, “the staff got Youth B off of me. I got up
immediately and left the building. There were all female staff and
one elderly male staff here in the building.”
I interviewed Staff 3 jointly with Government Worker 1. She has
worked at the facility for one month and worked in the Wayne
County Jail prior to that. Staff 3 said she went to the second-floor
lounge after hearing commotion. “It was dark, and Youth B and
Staff 1 were on the floor. Youth E was stomping Staff 1’s side.
We tried to pry them apart and push Youth E away. We tried to
intervene taking Youth E’s hands, but Youth E and Youth B are
7

big guys. Once we pushed Youth E back, Staff 1 was able to get
out…Staff 1 was coherent. He didn’t do anything wrong. I don’t
remember Staff 1 choking Youth B. His arms were around Youth
B’s arms to keep Youth B from punching and hitting him.”
Shortly after the incident, Staff 3 said Youth B went in the
bathroom, pulled a pipe and sink bowl off of the wall, then stated
he was having an anxiety attack with difficulty breathing. An
ambulance was called, and the youth was transported to
Beaumont Emergency Department.
Video of second floor lounge on 1/15/23
The camera view begins cloudy. Youth B and Staff 1 are sitting
across the room from each other. Youth E walks into the room,
says something to Staff 1 and walks out. Youth E returns and sits
in a chair facing Youth B with his back to Staff 1. Both youths
stand up together and Youth B sets a chair in position for Youth E
to stand on. Youth E covers the camera lens with his hand for 9
seconds. When he uncovers the camera, Youth B and Staff 1 are
not seen. They appear to be on the floor behind a table for the
next 20 seconds. Youth E watches them struggle on the floor
then leaves the room presumably to see if someone is coming.
Youth E reenters the room and starts pulling at someone on the
floor. 26 seconds later, six staff enter the room one by one.
Youth E is standing over Staff 1 punching him while Staff 1 is on
the floor struggling to free himself from Youth B. A male staff is
finally able to pull Youth E off of Staff 1. Youth B and Staff 1
remain on the floor but cannot be seen because six staff and
Youth E are standing around them. Youth E keeps trying to get at
Staff 1 while several staff attempt to block him. One female staff
physically tries to help Staff 1 while Youth E darts and jumps
around the area. Staff 1 and Youth B come into view. Staff 1 is
on his back on the floor and Youth B is on his back lying on top of
Staff 1. Staff 1 has his legs wrapped around Youth B’s
midsection. From beneath him, Staff 1 briefly has his arm
wrapped around the front of Youth B’s neck. Two female staff pull
Youth B up by his arms to a standing position. Youth B turns back
to get at Staff 1 again who is sat up on the floor. Youth E and
Youth B continue to approach Staff 1 aggressively while various
staff hold him back. Staff 1 is finally able to stand and move
himself out of the room while Youths B and Youth E are pushing
through staff to follow him. Youth B removes his t-shirt. Staff
block the doorway to prevent him from exiting. Youth B paces
aggressively shirtless around the room for 30 seconds then
breaks through a female staff and exits the room. 25 seconds
later Youth B reenters the room alone.
8

Government Worker 1 had findings.
ALLEGATION 2
On 1/1/24, an unidentified staff threw an unidentified youth to the
ground and choked him.
INVESTIGATION
Documents reviewed:
An incident report was requested onsite on 1/25/24 and not
available. I requested it again via email on 2/2/24. On 2/7/24 CA
told us there was only one incident report written by Supervisor 1
who did not witness the event. Supervisor 2’s incident report was
missing, and Staff 5 did not complete one.
Interviews:
On 1/25/24 CA identified Supervisor 2 and Youth B as involved in
the incident. She refuted the allegation and clarified that Youth B
attacked Supervisor 2 and not the reverse. She said Youth B was
transferred to Muskegon County Juvenile Transition Center on
1/16/24 and Supervisor 2 was still on medical leave as a result of
this incident.
Video for this incident was requested. On 2/7/24, CA told us there
was no video because it happened in the first-floor stairwell under
the camera. Government Worker 1 asked CA to recheck video of
the second-floor stairwell. On 2/11/24 CA emailed explaining the
entire incident lasted over an hour, there was no useful video on
the 2nd floor stairwell due to the lights being off, the camera angle
in relation to where Supervisor 2 was attacked, and the duration of
the assault.
According to CA, video footage did not capture this incident.
However, she provided a still photo taken by Supervisor 1
showing Youth B with Supervisor 2 in a headlock with Staff 5 in
the background.
Supervisor 1 resigned on 2/17/24 and could not be interviewed.
Courtesy Worker interviewed Youth B. He denied any incidents
took place at Wolverine Center other than what was discussed in
allegation 1.
9

I interviewed Youth E jointly with Government Worker 1 via Teams
on 2/7/24. Youth E presented with a silly demeanor, laughing and
untruthful about the facts relative to the incidents in which he was
involved. He claimed he did not witness this incident and
mentioned nothing about kicking the unit door open, seeing Youth
B with Supervisor 2 in a headlock, teaming up with Youth B to pull
at Supervisor 2 or being questioned by the police that night.
I interviewed Supervisor 2 jointly with Government Worker 1 on
2/7/24. He said the incident happened on his second day on the
job. He suffered a herniated disc as a result and has been on
medical leave since then. Supervisor 2 said the incident lasted for
over an hour and insisted he wrote an incident report. He was
surprised to hear the report could not be located.
Regarding the incident on 1/1/24 at 7pm, Supervisor 2 said he
saw Youth B and Youth J running around outdoors. “I opened a
door, and they rushed in past me to the stairwell.” Apparently, the
police had already been called and supervisors did not want the
youths back on the units until they were sufficiently checked in.
Supervisor 2 continued. “I was in the stairwell with Youths B and
Youth J. The first-floor unit door opened, and Youth B grabbed
my shirt. I grabbed his left arm. Another male staff tried to help
get Youth B off of me. Youth B was verbally threatening me. He
let go of me and I left. The male staff with him had a relationship
with Youth B and they stayed talking. Thirty minutes later I heard
Youth E was awake. I went upstairs because I believed Youth E
would let Youth B and Youth J inside of the unit. I was in the
stairwell and Youth E opened the unit door aggressively kicking it.
Youth B put his arm around my neck in a headlock. Youth E
grabbed my arm, and they pulled me back and forth. I tried to use
the CPI push-pull technique to get them off. They rushed me
again and we all fell. Youth B took my ID trying to antagonize me.
The police arrived and assisted (me). They took Youth B and
Youth E downstairs and questioned them. I went to Ascension
(Health Clinic) and was diagnosed with a herniated and bulging
disc.”
Supervisor 2 denied choking Youth B, stating “I never touched his
chest, neck, or anything. He said he saw no marks or bruises on
Youth B afterward.
I interviewed Staff 5 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for five months. On 1/1/24, Staff 5 recalled
Youth B and Youth E had locked a male staff in the gym. Later,
he said he was called to assist Supervisor 2 in the stairwell. “I
10

looked through the first floor into the landing to the stairwell.
Youth B and Supervisor 2 were in each other’s arms…I slid my
arm between both of them and whispered softly in Youth B’s ear.
Youth B went down to the ground and said he was ‘good’. I got
Supervisor 2 free. I was the only other male staff (in the building).
I kept Youth B and Youth J in the hallway waiting for police. Then
I went to assist someone else.” I asked Staff 5 to describe Youth
B’s state of mind. He described someone who is responding to
internal stimuli. Staff 5 stated “I don’t think Youth B exists in
reality. I feel he’s losing touch with reality. He has layers of
thoughts that make no sense.”
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis ALLEGATION 1
Before six staff arrived to assist him, Staff 1 admitted he used a
martial arts chokehold applied from behind Youth B. Choking a
youth is considered physical punishment and prohibited by the
rule.
(Violation Established)
ALLEGATION 2
There was no evidence Supervisor 2 threw a youth to the ground
and choked him. Conversely a photo taken during part of the
incident showed Youth B had Supervisor 2 in a headlock.
(Violation Not Established)
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
11

Allegation An unidentified staff told an unidentified youth who went absent
without leave (AWOL) that he would be dead. Manager was
aware and did not address the staff.
Investigation Interviews:
CA said she was unaware of any incident involving an unidentified
staff telling an unidentified youth who had gone AWOL that he
would be dead. She identified Youth E as a youth who went
AWOL in January 2024.
I interviewed Youth E jointly with Government Worker 1. He did
not mention that any staff told him he would be dead before,
because or upon returning from AWOL.
Courtesy Worker interviewed Youth B at the Muskegon County
Juvenile Transition Center. He denied ever going AWOL from
Wolverine Center.
Document Reviewed
The incident report documenting Youth E’s AWOL did not indicate
that a staff person told him he would be dead.
Analysis There is no evidence staff verbally abused or used derogatory
language pertaining to Youth E’s AWOL.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Around 1/12/24 an unidentified youth was vomiting and did not
receive timely medical attention. He was later taken to the
hospital and diagnosed with RSV or pneumonia.
Investigation Interviews:
CA identified the youth who was taken to the hospital as Youth S.
Government Worker 1 and I attempted to interview Youth S on
1/25/24. He came to the doorway of the interview room and
refused to talk with investigators.
12

Documents reviewed:
A Behavior Notification dated 1/12/24 indicated “Youth S woke up
at 11:00pm feeling bad. His throat and head were hurting. Also
stomach pains.” Youth S was sent to the hospital and has a virus
called RSV.
Hospital discharge paperwork dated 1/12/24 indicates Youth S
was examined at Beaumont Grosse Point Emergency
Department, diagnosed with Respiratory Syncytial Virus Infection
(RSV), and prescribed Ibuprofen.
A Behavior Notification dated 1/14/24 at 3:41am indicated Youth S
has a cold. He continued to spit and possibly threw up phlegm.
Youth S refused a pan to spit in and pain medication. He went
back to sleep and refused to get up to clean or allow staff to. He
threw up on the floor.
A Behavior Notification dated 1/14/24 at 8:40am indicated Youth S
woke up throwing up and complaining of a sore throat. He
continued throwing up non-stop. Youth S was diagnosed with
RSV on 1/12/24. Youth S was taken to Beaumont (again) today at
8:45am, admitted at 3:30pm and transferred to Beaumont Hospital
in Royal Oak.
Hospital Discharge paperwork dated 1/15/24 indicates Youth S
was seen at Beaumont University Hospital on 1/14/24 – 1/15/24.
He was diagnosed with community acquired pneumonia of left
lower lobe of lung and prescribed an antibiotic and Tylenol.
Analysis Youth S was seen at the emergency room on 1/12/24. On 1/14/24
he was seen again and admitted. Youth S was discharged from
Beaumont Hospital on 1/15/24. There is no evidence he did not
receive timely medical attention.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-child
Description ratio formula for direct care workers. If a child caring institution is
contracted by the department to care for youth, the facility will
follow its contracted ratio.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
13

Allegation On unidentified date(s), the staff to resident ratio was not met.
Investigation Document reviewed:
I reviewed the facility’s program statement indicating a ratio of 1:2
in the short-term shelter program and 1:3 in the treatment
program.
A staff schedule for dayshift 1/25/24 was provided indicating the
facility was working within ratio on that shift.
Interviews:
CA stated the ratio of staff to youth is 1:2 in the shelter program
and 1:3 in the treatment program. To her knowledge, the facility
has met their stated ratios in both programs for at least the past
month. CA said they have been mandating three or four staff to
work overtime on each shift and a group of new hires are currently
in training.
I interviewed Supervisor 3 jointly with Government Worker 1. She
has worked at the facility for one year as the midnight shift
supervisor. Supervisor 3 said on Sunday 1/21/24, one staff no
showed for her shift leaving a floor out of ratio from 2pm – 3:15pm
until Supervisor 3 was able to find coverage.
Analysis Supervisor 3 admitted the facility was working out of ratio for
about an hour on 1/21/24 dayshift.
CONSULTATION
It is recommended the agency add in the appropriate policy that
direct care and supervisory staff are not permitted to leave at the
end of their shift until they are properly relieved or granted specific
approval from the administrator.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4112 Criminal history, subject to requirements; staff
Section qualifications.
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
14

Allegation Unidentified Supervisor allows an unidentified youth to have
cigarettes and a lighter, and to smoke in the bathroom.
Investigation Interviews:
CA said she was unaware of any supervisor or staff allowing a
youth to have cigarettes or a lighter. She said no smoking
paraphernalia was confiscated in the facility in January 2024.
Youth E denied seeing any youths with cigarettes or smoking in
the facility.
Courtesy Worker interviewed Youth B at the Muskegon County
Juvenile Transition Center. Asked if the children at Wolverine
were allowed to do anything illegal such as smoke or drink, he
stated "no" then started laughing. Asked if he was laughing at the
question, or because he did things, he did not want to tell the
worker, Youth B responded, "The second one". Asked if he
smoked at Wolverine, he answered, “Yes” and laughed. He
refused to elaborate and would not say how he got an illegal
substance or what staff were working when he smoked. Youth B
reiterated he did not want to say too much, did not want it written
down and that it did not matter.
Analysis Youth B claimed he smoked inside the facility, but refused to say
where, when, what or how he managed to smoke. There is no
evidence anyone allowed Youth B to smoke in the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing;
Section storage space.
Description (1) A licensee shall have a written policy that designates all of the
following:
(c) The method for ensuring that each resident has sufficient
clean, properly fitting, seasonal clothing.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youths went without clean clothes and towels for
approximately one month.
Investigation Onsite inspection
On 1/25/24 I observed six functioning washers and dryers, and
several bags of dirty clothes in the basement waiting to be
washed.
15

Interviews:
CA said the facility has six washers and six dryers. At one point,
four of the twelve machines were not working, but they have since
been repaired. During the time the machines were broken, CA
said all youths still had clean clothes and towels.
Supervisor 3 said to her knowledge, youths have never gone
without clean clothes or towels. They receive new outfits (t-shirt,
sweatpants, underwear, sweatshirt, and towels) daily or as
needed.
Director of Operations and Facilities stated youths are responsible
to bag and set their dirty clothes outside their room to be washed.
Youth E said youths are supposed to (bag and) set their dirty
clothes outside their rooms to be washed, “but we don’t.”
Because he was non-compliant, he said he once waited a week
before his clothes were washed. “I’d say (to staff) ‘This bitch is
getting shut the fuck down, and they would do it,’” he bragged.
Document reviewed:
A printed internal email dated 1/17/24 indicated a washing
machine technician was onsite at the facility.
There is no written policy describing the laundry procedure.
Analysis At one time four of twelve washer and dryers were not working.
Visual observation and documentation indicated the machines
have since been repaired. Since youths are responsible for
bagging their dirty clothes and setting them in the halls to be
washed, some youths do not comply and as a result may go
without clean clothes for longer than necessary.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & Rule 400.4109 Program statement

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
It is essential that the primary staff person or persons directly
involved in the event write incident reports. Reports by staff who
verbally or physically responded and/or intervened are also
recommended. Reports by staff who witnessed the incident but
did not intervene may also be useful. All incident reports should

sir_summary.summary: The report details an investigation into multiple allegations at Wolverine Center, a child caring institution. Several allegations, including inadequate heating, lack of cleaning supplies, verbal abuse, and delayed medical care, were not substantiated. However, the investigation did substantiate three violations: a staff member used a prohibited martial arts chokehold on a youth, the facility operated out of its required staff-to-youth ratio for a period, and staff failed to write incident reports as required by internal policy. The culpability lies primarily with the facility's staff and supervision, as evidenced by the use of prohibited physical intervention and failures in procedural compliance.

sir_violation_level.justification: The report substantiated a violation of Rule 400.4158 for physical punishment, specifically that Staff 1 used a martial arts chokehold on a youth. This falls under the 'Safety and Violence' category (staff-on-youth violence) and the 'Restraint and seclusion' category (use of physical restraints/excessive force) as defined in the severe SIR criteria.
